question: My husband beats me and tortures me mentally.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 85 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), which deals with cruelty by husband or his relatives. This section covers both physical and mental cruelty against a woman by her husband or his family members. You should immediately report to the nearest police station or call the women’s helpline (1091). The offence is cognizable and non-bailable, punishable with imprisonment up to three years and fine.

question: My husband forces me to have physical relations against my will.
answer: You can file a case under Section 63 of the BNS, which defines sexual assault in a gender-neutral manner. If your husband forces you into sexual acts without your consent, it amounts to sexual assault. Marital rape is recognized as cruelty under Section 85 and can be taken up in combination with Section 63. You can approach the police or protection officer under the Domestic Violence Act for immediate protection and legal aid.

question: My husband demands dowry and threatens to leave me if I don’t fulfill it.
answer: You can register a case under Section 85 of the BNS for cruelty and also under the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961. Demanding dowry or harassing a woman for dowry is a punishable offence. You should collect any messages or witnesses and report to the police or women’s cell. The punishment can extend up to five years of imprisonment and fine.

question: My husband frequently abuses me verbally and calls me names.
answer: You can complain under Section 85 of the BNS for mental cruelty. Repeated verbal abuse that causes emotional trauma or affects your mental health falls under this section. You can also seek protection and residence orders under the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005. The husband can face imprisonment up to three years and fine.

question: My husband locked me inside the house and doesn’t allow me to go out.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 120 of the BNS for wrongful confinement. This section punishes anyone who restrains or confines a person illegally. Such actions also constitute mental cruelty under Section 85. You should contact the police or call the women’s helpline for immediate rescue and legal protection.

question: My husband took all my salary and controls my bank account.
answer: You can complain under Section 316 of the BNS for cheating and dishonest misappropriation of property. If your husband forces or deceives you into giving him your earnings, it amounts to financial abuse. You should provide proof such as bank statements or transfers. The offence is punishable with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

question: My husband constantly threatens to kill me if I leave him.
answer: You can register a case under Section 351 of the BNS for criminal intimidation. Threatening to cause death or harm is a serious offence. You can record or save any threatening messages and report them to the police. The punishment can extend up to seven years of imprisonment and fine.

question: My husband shared my private photos without my consent.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 67 of the BNS for publishing or transmitting obscene material, and under Section 66E of the IT Act for violation of privacy. This is a serious offence involving breach of trust and dignity. You can file a complaint with the cybercrime cell or at cybercrime.gov.in. The punishment can extend up to five years of imprisonment and fine.

question: My husband left me without giving financial support for months.
answer: You can seek legal remedy under Section 85 of the BNS for cruelty and also file a case for maintenance under Section 125 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita (BNSS) or through family court. Abandoning a wife without providing for her basic needs amounts to cruelty. The court can order maintenance and take action against him for neglect.

question: My husband pushed me during an argument and I got injured.
answer: You can report under Section 115(2) of the BNS for voluntarily causing hurt. This section covers intentional physical harm or injury. You should get a medical certificate and file an FIR. The offence is punishable with imprisonment up to one year or fine or both, depending on the severity of the injury.

question: My husband forced me to leave my job against my will.
answer: You can complain under Section 85 of the BNS for mental cruelty and economic abuse. Restricting a woman’s right to work or forcing her to quit amounts to harassment. You can also seek relief under the Domestic Violence Act. The court can issue protection, residence, and maintenance orders.

question: My husband publicly insults me on social media.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 351 of the BNS for criminal intimidation and defamation, and also under the IT Act for online harassment. Public humiliation causing damage to your reputation is punishable with imprisonment and fine. You can collect screenshots and report through the cybercrime portal or at the local police station.

question: My husband prevents me from talking to my parents or friends.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 85 of the BNS for mental cruelty. Isolating a woman from her family and controlling her communication is a form of psychological abuse. You can also seek protection under the Domestic Violence Act, which ensures your right to live with dignity and freedom.

question: My husband forces me to do household work even when I am unwell.
answer: You can complain under Section 85 of the BNS for cruelty and harassment. Forcing a woman to perform tasks against her will or when sick amounts to mental and physical cruelty. You can approach the local police or protection officer for support and legal remedy.

question: My husband beats our children and threatens me not to intervene.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 85 of the BNS for cruelty, as well as under child protection laws such as the Juvenile Justice Act and POCSO Act if the children are minors. The act of physical violence towards children or threats to silence you is a punishable offence. You should immediately contact the police or Childline (1098).

question: My husband threatens to harm my parents if I complain against him.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 351 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) for criminal intimidation. Threatening to harm your family members to silence you is a serious offence. You should record the threats if possible and inform the police immediately. The punishment can extend up to seven years of imprisonment and fine.

question: My husband forces me to bring money from my parents for his business.
answer: You can report the matter under Section 85 of the BNS for cruelty by husband or his relatives. Demanding money or property from the wife’s family is treated as harassment and can also attract charges under the Dowry Prohibition Act. The punishment includes imprisonment up to three years and fine.

question: My husband blackmails me with private photos to control me.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 67 of the BNS for publishing or threatening to publish obscene material, and under Section 66E of the IT Act for violation of privacy. This constitutes digital blackmail and cruelty. You can report through the cybercrime portal (cybercrime.gov.in) or at your local police station. The punishment can extend up to five years of imprisonment and fine.

question: My husband is having an extra-marital affair and harasses me emotionally.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 85 of the BNS for mental cruelty. Extramarital affairs that cause emotional trauma, humiliation, or harassment are recognized as cruelty under the law. You can also seek divorce and maintenance under the family court’s jurisdiction. The husband can face imprisonment up to three years and fine.

question: My husband keeps all my jewellery and refuses to return it.
answer: You can register a case under Section 316 of the BNS for criminal breach of trust or misappropriation of property. Refusing to return a woman’s ‘stridhan’ (jewellery or valuables given to her) is a punishable offence. You should provide proof of ownership and make a written complaint to the police. The offence is punishable with imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

question: My husband locks me in a room whenever he is angry.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 120 of the BNS for wrongful confinement and under Section 85 for cruelty. Physically confining someone against their will is a serious human rights violation. You should contact the police immediately or call the women’s helpline for rescue and legal support. The punishment can include imprisonment up to three years and fine.

question: My husband forces me to sign documents I don’t understand.
answer: You can file a case under Section 336 of the BNS for forgery or Section 316 for cheating, depending on the intent. Forcing you to sign documents without consent or understanding is illegal and punishable. You should keep copies of any such documents and inform the police or legal aid office.

question: My husband abuses me in front of my children and relatives.
answer: You can report under Section 85 of the BNS for cruelty and mental harassment. Public humiliation and verbal abuse intended to degrade your dignity are punishable. You can approach the police, local women’s cell, or Protection Officer under the Domestic Violence Act. The husband can face imprisonment up to three years and fine.

question: My husband is addicted to alcohol and beats me when drunk.
answer: You can register a complaint under Section 85 of the BNS for cruelty. Physical violence under intoxication does not excuse the offence. The police can arrest him for domestic violence, and you may seek a protection order and residence order under the Domestic Violence Act. The offence is punishable with imprisonment up to three years and fine.

question: My husband continuously monitors my phone and messages without my permission.
answer: You can complain under Section 63 of the BNS for sexual or personal harassment and under Section 66E of the IT Act for violation of privacy. Monitoring your private communications without consent amounts to digital stalking and breach of trust. You can report the matter to the cybercrime cell or police for legal action. The punishment can extend up to three years of imprisonment and fine.

question: My husband beats me and causes injury.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 85 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) for voluntarily causing hurt or Section 86 for causing grievous hurt. If the violence is continuous and amounts to cruelty, you can also file under Section 85(2) and seek protection under domestic violence laws.

question: My husband harasses me for dowry.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 74 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) for cruelty by husband or his relatives. The section covers both mental and physical cruelty, including harassment for dowry, and is punishable with imprisonment up to three years and fine.

question: My husband threatens to kill me.
answer: This is a serious criminal intimidation offence under Section 351 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS). You can file a complaint at the nearest police station for criminal intimidation, and if the threat involves death or grievous hurt, stricter punishment applies.

question: My husband forces me into sexual relations against my will.
answer: You can report the crime under Section 63 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), which defines rape. Forced sexual intercourse without consent, even within marriage (if separated or under certain conditions), constitutes an offence and is punishable with rigorous imprisonment.

question: My husband shares my private photos without consent.
answer: This act falls under Section 69 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) for insulting the modesty of a woman and also under Section 67 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA) and IT Act provisions related to transmission of obscene material. You can file both a cyber and police complaint.

question: My husband abuses me verbally and mentally every day.
answer: You can register a case under Section 74 of the BNS for cruelty by husband, as mental harassment and verbal abuse are recognized as cruelty. You can also seek protection under the Domestic Violence Act for immediate relief.

question: My husband locks me inside the house and restricts my movement.
answer: This is wrongful confinement under Section 124 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS). You can lodge a complaint against your husband for illegally restraining your liberty, which is punishable by imprisonment.

question: My husband takes away my salary and controls all my money.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 303 of the BNS for criminal breach of trust. If he misuses or takes your property without consent, it also amounts to cruelty under Section 74.

question: My husband brings another woman home and lives with her.
answer: This constitutes adultery and emotional cruelty. While adultery is no longer a criminal offence, you can seek legal remedy under matrimonial laws and also file for cruelty under Section 74 of BNS.

question: My husband blackmails me with private messages and photos.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 351 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) for criminal intimidation and under the IT Act Section 66E for violation of privacy. These acts are punishable with imprisonment and fine.

question: My husband throws me out of the house without any support.
answer: You can file a complaint under Section 74 of the BNS for cruelty. Additionally, you can seek maintenance and residence rights under the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005.

question: My husband refuses to give me money for household expenses or children’s education.
answer: This is a form of economic abuse and cruelty under Section 74 of the BNS. You can file for maintenance under Section 125 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita (BNSS) and seek relief under the Domestic Violence Act.

question: My husband forces me to leave my job against my will.
answer: You can take legal action under Section 74 of the BNS for cruelty and mental harassment, as it restricts your personal freedom and economic independence.

question: My husband constantly insults my parents and relatives.
answer: Repeated humiliation and verbal abuse towards your family amount to mental cruelty under Section 74 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS). You can lodge a complaint and seek protection under the Domestic Violence Act.

question: My husband records my private moments without consent.
answer: You can file a case under Section 69 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) for outraging the modesty of a woman, and also under Section 66E of the IT Act for violation of privacy. Both carry imprisonment and fine.

question: My boss touches me inappropriately at work.
answer: You can file a complaint under Sec 74 BNS for sexual harassment. Unwanted physical contact or advances at the workplace are punishable by imprisonment up to 3 years and fine. You should report the incident to the Internal Committee at your workplace or directly to the police. Keep records of any witnesses or messages as evidence.

question: My senior makes vulgar comments about my appearance.
answer: This falls under Sec 74 BNS for sexually coloured remarks and verbal harassment. Repeated offensive comments at the workplace are punishable. Maintain written records or screenshots if the comments are digital, and report to the Internal Committee or police to ensure action is taken.

question: My manager asks for sexual favours in exchange for promotion.
answer: Such conduct is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Offering promotions in exchange for sexual favours is a serious offence. File a complaint with the Internal Committee and police immediately. The offender can face imprisonment up to 3 years and fine.

question: My colleague sends me obscene photos and messages online.
answer: You can file a complaint under Sec 74 BNS for sexual harassment. Sending obscene or sexually explicit content without consent is punishable. Preserve the messages or photos as evidence and report the matter to the Internal Committee or cybercrime branch of the police.

question: My boss tries to hug or kiss me without my consent.
answer: Unwanted physical advances at the workplace constitute sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. You should clearly reject the advances, document the incident, and file a complaint with the Internal Committee or police. Such acts are punishable with imprisonment and fine.

question: My office colleague shows me pornographic videos against my will.
answer: This is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Showing pornographic content without consent at the workplace is illegal. Report the incident to your Internal Committee and keep any evidence such as video files or screenshots for legal proceedings.

question: My manager keeps calling me to his cabin for personal talks and makes me uncomfortable.
answer: Repeated unwelcome personal meetings can amount to sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Document the dates, times, and content of conversations, and report the behaviour to the Internal Committee or police to prevent escalation.

question: My colleague tries to hold my hand or brush against me intentionally.
answer: This counts as sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Unwanted physical gestures or touching are punishable. Immediately inform HR or the Internal Committee, collect witness statements if possible, and file a police complaint.

question: My boss threatens to fire me if I don’t agree to go out with him.
answer: This is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS and criminal intimidation under Sec 351 BNS. You should document the threats, preserve messages, and report the matter to both the Internal Committee and police. The offender can face imprisonment and fine for both offences.

question: My supervisor makes jokes about my body in front of others.
answer: Sexually coloured jokes or humiliation at work fall under Sec 74 BNS. You should document the instances, note witnesses, and report to the Internal Committee or police. The offender can face legal consequences including imprisonment up to 3 years and fine.

question: My colleague deliberately follows me after office hours.
answer: This is stalking under Sec 77 BNS. Repeatedly following someone against their will is punishable. You should document the behaviour, note dates and times, and file a complaint with police for immediate action.

question: My team leader secretly takes my photos without permission.
answer: Secretly taking photos without consent falls under Sec 69 BNS (insulting modesty) and Sec 74 BNS for sexual harassment. Preserve any evidence and report to the Internal Committee or police. The offender is liable for imprisonment and fine.

question: My boss spreads false rumours about me having an affair with him.
answer: Defamation and harassment in such cases fall under Sec 354 BNS and Sec 74 BNS. You should collect evidence, witnesses, and report the matter to police or Internal Committee. The offender can face imprisonment and fine.

question: My office HR refuses to register my harassment complaint.
answer: Even if Internal Committee or HR refuses, you can directly approach the police under Sec 74 BNS for sexual harassment. Document your complaint in writing and keep copies for future legal proceedings.

question: My boss touches my shoulder or back often despite my objections.
answer: Repeated unwanted physical contact is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. You should reject the behaviour clearly, document every instance, and file a complaint with the Internal Committee or police. The offender is punishable with imprisonment and fine.

question: My boss asks me inappropriate questions about my personal life.
answer: This counts as sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Asking unwelcome personal or sexual questions at the workplace is punishable. Document the dates, questions, and witnesses, and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My colleague makes lewd gestures at me during meetings.
answer: You can file under Sec 74 BNS for sexual harassment. Unwanted gestures or expressions of sexual nature are punishable with imprisonment and fine. Keep evidence like emails, recordings, or witnesses.

question: My manager comments on my clothing in a sexual way.
answer: Sexually coloured comments fall under Sec 74 BNS. Repeated comments that make you uncomfortable are harassment. Report to Internal Committee or police and document instances.

question: My boss repeatedly sends me private messages late at night.
answer: Unwanted messages can be harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Document all messages and timestamps, and report to Internal Committee or police for action.

question: My colleague spreads sexual rumours about me in the office.
answer: This is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS and defamation. Collect evidence, note witnesses, and report to Internal Committee or police. The offender is punishable with imprisonment and fine.

question: My manager touches my desk items to peek into my personal files.
answer: This constitutes sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Invading privacy intentionally is punishable. Document evidence and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My boss makes sexual jokes about me in front of other employees.
answer: Sexually coloured jokes or humiliation fall under Sec 74 BNS. Repeated acts are punishable. Maintain records of dates, witnesses, and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My colleague keeps sending me emojis or symbols with sexual meaning.
answer: This is harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Unwanted sexual communication through digital messages is punishable. Preserve evidence and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My manager pressures me to meet him outside office for personal reasons.
answer: This is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Refusing the meeting should be documented, and complaint filed with Internal Committee or police.

question: My boss makes repeated comments about my body after I said no.
answer: Repeated unwanted comments fall under Sec 74 BNS. Document every instance and report to Internal Committee or police. Offender is liable for imprisonment and fine.

question: My colleague blocks me in office corridors and tries to touch me.
answer: This is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Physical obstruction and unwanted contact are punishable. Report to Internal Committee or police immediately.

question: My manager insists I sit next to him despite my objections.
answer: This counts as sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Repeated unwelcome proximity is punishable. Document instances and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My colleague records me secretly during office hours.
answer: Secret recording without consent falls under Sec 69 BNS (insulting modesty) and Sec 74 BNS. Preserve evidence and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My boss sends me inappropriate links or videos during work hours.
answer: This is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Preserve messages or screenshots and report to Internal Committee or police. The offence is punishable with imprisonment and fine.

question: My colleague keeps following me on social media despite my objections.
answer: This is stalking and harassment under Sec 77 BNS. Repeated unwanted contact or following is punishable. Document instances and report to police.

question: My boss keeps sending me unwanted friend requests and messages online.
answer: This is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Unsolicited digital contact with sexual undertones is punishable. Preserve screenshots and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My colleague makes inappropriate comments about my voice or way of speaking.
answer: Verbal sexual harassment falls under Sec 74 BNS. Repeated offensive remarks are punishable. Document incidents and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My manager stares at me in a way that makes me uncomfortable.
answer: Unwelcome sexual attention through gestures or staring is harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Maintain evidence, note witnesses, and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My boss forces me to attend personal meetings after office hours.
answer: This counts as sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Repeated unwelcome meetings are punishable. Document each instance and file a complaint with Internal Committee or police.

question: My colleague tries to touch me under the pretext of helping with work.
answer: Unwanted physical contact at workplace is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Report immediately to Internal Committee or police, and document witnesses.

question: My manager asks me personal questions about my dating life.
answer: This is harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Unwelcome questions about personal or sexual life are punishable. Keep a written record and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My colleague makes jokes about my body parts in group chats.
answer: Sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS applies. Offensive digital communication is punishable. Preserve chat logs and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My boss spreads false sexual rumours about me among colleagues.
answer: Defamation and harassment fall under Sec 354 BNS and Sec 74 BNS. Document evidence, note witnesses, and file complaint with Internal Committee or police.

question: My manager touches my chair or desk area to get close to me.
answer: This constitutes sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Document each incident and report to Internal Committee or police for action.

question: My colleague keeps sending me sexual memes or GIFs.
answer: This is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Preserve digital evidence and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My boss repeatedly compliments my body despite my objections.
answer: Unwelcome comments fall under Sec 74 BNS. Keep detailed records of dates, witnesses, and report to Internal Committee or police.

question: My colleague follows me to the cafeteria and tries to corner me.
answer: This is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Document incidents, note witnesses, and report to Internal Committee or police immediately.

question: My manager asks me to share personal photos under the pretext of work.
answer: Requesting personal photos is harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Do not comply, preserve evidence, and file complaint with Internal Committee or police.

question: My colleague keeps sending me messages implying sexual favours are expected.
answer: This is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Save messages and report to Internal Committee or police. The offender can face imprisonment and fine.

question: My boss deliberately blocks my exit and tries to touch me.
answer: This is sexual harassment under Sec 74 BNS. Physical intimidation or touching is punishable. Document evidence and report immediately to Internal Committee or police.

question: Someone hacked my office email and sent fraudulent messages.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating (hacking and unauthorised access). The offender can face imprisonment and fine. Preserve logs, emails, and report to the cybercrime cell or police immediately.

question: Someone created a fake invoice in my name to divert company funds.
answer: This is fraud under Section 336 BNS (cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property). Collect all documents and evidence, and file a complaint with police or cybercrime authorities.

question: Someone impersonates me online to scam clients.
answer: Identity fraud falls under Section 318 BNS for cheating (identity theft) and Section 336 BNS (cheating). Preserve all online evidence and file complaint with police or cybercrime unit.

question: Someone sent me an email claiming I won a lottery but it asks for bank details.
answer: This is phishing and cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating. Do not share personal info, preserve email as evidence, and report to cybercrime authorities immediately.

question: Someone cloned my debit card using my personal information.
answer: Card fraud is punishable under Section 336 BNS (cheating) and Section 318 BNS for cheating (unauthorised access to bank details). Inform the bank, preserve statements, and lodge police complaint.

question: Someone created a fake social media account in my name to defraud others.
answer: This is impersonation and cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating. Collect screenshots and report to cybercrime authorities and police.

question: Someone sent fake tax refund emails to collect sensitive info.
answer: This constitutes fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating and Section 336 BNS. Preserve emails and report to cybercrime cell or police for action.

question: Someone hacked into my company database and stole confidential client data.
answer: Data theft is cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating. Preserve evidence of breach, inform authorities, and file a complaint to prevent further damage.

question: Someone offered me a fake job online asking for registration fees.
answer: This is online fraud under Section 336 BNS. Do not pay, preserve messages, and report to cybercrime cell and police.

question: Someone used my login credentials to transfer company funds illegally.
answer: This is cheating and cyber fraud under Section 336 BNS and Section 318 BNS for cheating. Report the incident with proof to police and cybercrime authorities.

question: Someone created a fake online store to collect payments and never deliver products.
answer: This is cheating under Section 336 BNS. Preserve transaction evidence and lodge a complaint with police or cybercrime unit.

question: Someone sent me a message claiming my bank account is frozen and asks for OTP.
answer: This is phishing and fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating. Never share OTP or credentials. Preserve the message and report to cybercrime authorities immediately.

question: Someone diverted my salary to their account using office software hack.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 336 BNS and Section 318 BNS for cheating. Preserve system logs and report to police and IT security authorities.

question: Someone sent a fake government grant email asking for bank details.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating and Section 336 BNS. Do not share personal info. Preserve evidence and report to cybercrime cell or police.

question: Someone made unauthorized cryptocurrency transactions from my account.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating. Preserve transaction records, inform your bank, and file a police/cybercrime complaint immediately.

question: Someone created a fake banking website to steal my login credentials.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating (phishing and unauthorised access). Preserve screenshots, do not enter personal info, and report to cybercrime cell or police immediately.

question: Someone sent me a fake investment link promising high returns.
answer: This is online fraud under Section 336 BNS. Do not invest, preserve the link and messages, and report to cybercrime authorities and police.

question: Someone hacked my social media account and sent scams to my contacts.
answer: Unauthorized access and cheating fall under Section 318 BNS for cheating and Section 336 BNS. Preserve evidence, change passwords, and file complaint with cybercrime cell or police.

question: Someone created a fake online store in my name to cheat customers.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 336 BNS (cheating). Collect screenshots, transaction records, and report to police or cybercrime authorities.

question: Someone sent me a message claiming I won a government grant and asked for bank details.
answer: This is phishing and cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating and Section 336 BNS. Do not share information, preserve evidence, and report to cybercrime authorities.

question: Someone accessed my email and changed all my passwords.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating (hacking and unauthorised access). Preserve logs, secure your accounts, and file complaint with cybercrime cell or police.

question: Someone created a fake charity online and collected donations in my name.
answer: This is cheating under Section 336 BNS. Preserve transaction records and report to police and cybercrime authorities for action.

question: Someone installed malware on my office computer to steal sensitive data.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating (hacking and unauthorised access). Preserve system logs and report to IT security team and police immediately.

question: Someone impersonated me on social media to request money from friends.
answer: Identity theft and fraud fall under Section 318 BNS for cheating and Section 336 BNS. Preserve screenshots and report to cybercrime authorities and police.

question: Someone diverted funds from my bank account using online banking fraud.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating and Section 336 BNS. Preserve bank statements and report to your bank and police immediately.

question: Someone sent a fake message claiming my PAN card is blocked and asked for details.
answer: This is phishing under Section 318 BNS for cheating. Do not share sensitive info, preserve the message, and report to cybercrime authorities.

question: Someone hacked my office database and deleted important financial records.
answer: This is cyber fraud and data tampering under Section 318 BNS for cheating. Preserve backups, logs, and file complaint with IT security and police.

question: Someone sent me a fake invoice for software I never purchased.
answer: This is cheating under Section 336 BNS. Preserve the invoice and report to police or cybercrime authorities for legal action.

question: Someone used my identity to create multiple fake email accounts for scams.
answer: Identity theft under Section 318 BNS for cheating and cheating under Section 336 BNS. Preserve all account details and report to cybercrime cell and police.

question: Someone sent me a fake payment link pretending to be my bank.
answer: This is phishing and cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating. Do not click the link, preserve the message, and report to cybercrime authorities immediately.

question: Someone sent me a fake invoice claiming I owe money for services I never used.
answer: This is cheating under Section 336 BNS. Preserve the invoice and related messages, and report to police or cybercrime authorities immediately.

question: Someone hacked into my social media account and posted defamatory content.
answer: This is cyber fraud and defamation under Section 318 BNS for cheating and Section 336 BNS. Preserve screenshots and report to cybercrime authorities and police.

question: Someone created a fake e-commerce site using my brand name to collect payments.
answer: This is cheating under Section 336 BNS. Collect evidence like website screenshots and payment records, and file a complaint with police or cybercrime authorities.

question: Someone sent me phishing emails pretending to be my bank and asked for OTP.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating. Do not share OTP, preserve emails, and report to cybercrime authorities and your bank.

question: Someone transferred money from my account using my stolen online banking credentials.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating and Section 336 BNS. Preserve bank statements and file complaint with bank and police immediately.

question: Someone created a fake job portal using my identity and collected fees from applicants.
answer: This is cheating under Section 336 BNS and identity fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating. Preserve evidence and report to police and cybercrime authorities.

question: Someone installed spyware on my phone to access sensitive personal data.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating (unauthorised access). Preserve evidence, remove spyware, and report to police and IT authorities.

question: Someone impersonated my bank and asked for confidential information via call and email.
answer: This is phishing and cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating. Do not share details, preserve communications, and report to cybercrime authorities and bank.

question: Someone hacked my office network and altered financial records to hide embezzlement.
answer: This is cyber fraud under Section 318 BNS for cheating. Preserve system logs and report to IT security team and police immediately.

question: Someone created a fake payment link to collect money from my clients.
answer: This is cheating under Section 336 BNS. Preserve transaction records and report to police or cybercrime authorities.

question: Someone used my credentials to open multiple fake accounts for online loans.
answer: This is identity theft under Section 318 BNS for cheating and cheating under Section 336 BNS. Preserve all evidence and report to police and cybercrime authorities.

question: Someone sent me a fake scholarship email asking for bank details.
answer: This is phishing under Section 318 BNS for cheating and cyber fraud. Do not share details, preserve message, and report to cybercrime authorities immediately.

question: Someone hacked my online cloud storage and deleted important files.
